options.label: D

options.label: C

options.label: D

title: The surprising habits of original thinkers - Adam Grant

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to describe people who are quick to start but slow to finish, and how does this trait affect their creativity?

options.label: A
options.text: Precrastinators, and it decreases their creativity.

options.label: B
options.text: Procrastinators, and it decreases their creativity.

options.label: C
options.text: Precrastinators, and it has no effect on their creativity.

options.label: D
options.text: Procrastinators, and it can actually boost their creativity.

multiple-choice.question: What is the difference between self-doubt and idea doubt, and how do they affect a person's creative process?

options.label: A
options.text: Self-doubt is energizing and motivates a person to test and refine their ideas, while idea doubt is paralyzing and leads to inaction.

options.label: B
options.text: Self-doubt is paralyzing and leads to inaction, while idea doubt is energizing and motivates a person to test and refine their ideas.

options.label: C
options.text: Self-doubt and idea doubt are the same thing and both lead to inaction.

options.label: D
options.text: Self-doubt and idea doubt are the same thing and both motivate a person to test and refine their ideas.

multiple-choice.question: What is the concept of "vuja de" and how does it relate to creativity and originality?

options.label: A
options.text: Vuja de is the feeling of déjà vu, and it is a sign of a lack of creativity and originality.

options.label: B
options.text: Vuja de is the opposite of déjà vu, and it is the ability to see something familiar with fresh eyes and a new perspective.

options.label: C
options.text: Vuja de is a type of creative block, and it prevents people from coming up with new ideas.

options.label: D
options.text: Vuja de is a type of brainstorming technique, and it involves generating as many ideas as possible in a short amount of time.

multiple-choice.question: What is the relationship between fear and creativity, and how do original people approach fear and risk-taking?

options.label: A
options.text: Fear is a major obstacle to creativity, and original people are those who are fearless and willing to take risks.

options.label: B
options.text: Fear is a necessary component of creativity, and original people are those who are able to harness their fear to motivate themselves.

options.label: C
options.text: Fear is not a factor in creativity, and original people are simply those who are more talented and skilled.

options.label: D
options.text: Fear is a natural part of the creative process, and original people are those who are willing to take risks and face their fears head-on.

multiple-choice.question: What is the key to generating more ideas and increasing one's chances of coming up with something truly original?

options.label: A
options.text: Focusing on a single idea and refining it to perfection.

options.label: B
options.text: Generating as many ideas as possible and increasing one's output.

options.label: C
options.text: Brainstorming with a group of people and building on each other's ideas.

options.label: D
options.text: Using a specific technique or formula to generate new ideas.

title: The imaginary king who changed the real world - Matteo Salvadore

What was the primary reason why European rulers were interested in finding Prester John's kingdom?

options.label: B
options.text: To find a powerful Christian ally in their war against Muslim armies

options.label: C
options.text: To spread Christianity to new regions

options.label: D
options.text: To explore new lands

options.label: B
options.text: A Mongol leader

options.label: C
options.text: The actual Prester John

title: Your brain hallucinates your conscious reality - Anil Seth

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what happens to our sense of time when we wake up from a deep sleep versus when we come round from anesthesia?

options.label: A
options.text: We feel confused about the time in both cases.

options.label: B
options.text: We feel a sense of continuity between then and now in both cases.

options.label: C
options.text: We feel confused about the time when waking from a deep sleep, but have no sense of time when coming round from anesthesia.

options.label: D
options.text: We have a sense of continuity between then and now when waking from a deep sleep, but not when coming round from anesthesia.

multiple-choice.question: What is the brain's role in perception, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: The brain passively receives signals from the outside world.

options.label: B
options.text: The brain actively generates our experience of the world.

options.label: C
options.text: The brain only perceives the world through our senses.

options.label: D
options.text: The brain has no role in perception.

multiple-choice.question: What is the rubber hand illusion, and what does it demonstrate?

options.label: A
options.text: It's an illusion where a person's real hand is hidden and a fake hand is stroked, demonstrating that our sense of touch is unreliable.

options.label: B
options.text: It's an illusion where a person's real hand is hidden and a fake hand is stroked, demonstrating that our brain can be tricked into thinking the fake hand is part of our body.

options.label: C
options.text: It's an illusion where a person's real hand is shown and a fake hand is hidden, demonstrating that our sense of sight is unreliable.

options.label: D
options.text: It's an illusion where a person's real hand is shown and a fake hand is hidden, demonstrating that our brain cannot be tricked into thinking the fake hand is part of our body.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the relationship between our experiences of the world and our living bodies?

options.label: A
options.text: Our experiences of the world are separate from our living bodies.

options.label: B
options.text: Our experiences of the world are shaped by our living bodies, but not dependent on them.

options.label: C
options.text: Our experiences of the world are dependent on our living bodies, but not shaped by them.

options.label: D
options.text: Our experiences of the world are both shaped by and dependent on our living bodies.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's conclusion about the nature of consciousness?

options.label: A
options.text: Consciousness is a product of the brain and can be reduced to a software program.

options.label: B
options.text: Consciousness is a product of the brain, but cannot be reduced to a software program.

options.label: C
options.text: Consciousness is not a product of the brain, but rather a separate entity.

options.label: D
options.text: Consciousness is an illusion and does not exist.

title: How one scientist took on the chemical industry - Mark Lytle

multiple-choice.question: What was the name of the book published by Rachel Carson in 1962 that documented the misuse of chemicals and their toll on nature and human health?

options.label: A
options.text: "The Ocean's Fury"

options.label: B
options.text: "Silent Spring"

options.label: C
options.text: "The Voices of Spring"

options.label: D
options.text: "The Balance of Nature"

multiple-choice.question: What was the original use of DDT during World War II?

options.label: A
options.text: To shield crops from insects and protect soldiers from insect-borne diseases

options.label: B
options.text: To eradicate fire ants in the southern U.S.

options.label: C
options.text: To control the threat of insects to human health

options.label: D
options.text: To accumulate in the environment and alter the structure of genes

multiple-choice.question: According to Rachel Carson, what was the potential harm of DDT to humans?

options.label: A
options.text: It could lead to the evolution of resistant species

options.label: B
options.text: It could accumulate in the environment and alter the structure of genes

options.label: C
options.text: It could control the threat of insects to human health

options.label: D
options.text: It could dissolve in water and have no impact on the environment

multiple-choice.question: What was the response of the US government to the publication of "Silent Spring"?

options.label: A
options.text: The government immediately banned the use of DDT

options.label: B
options.text: The government created the Environmental Protection Agency to enforce environmental regulations

options.label: C
options.text: The government dismissed Carson's claims and continued to promote the use of DDT

options.label: D
options.text: The government had no response to the publication of the book

multiple-choice.question: What was the outcome of the growing environmental movement sparked by Rachel Carson's book?

options.label: A
options.text: The movement failed to lead to any significant changes in environmental regulations

options.label: B
options.text: The movement led to the creation of the Environmental Protection Agency and the partial ban on the use of DDT

options.label: C
options.text: The movement led to the eradication of all environmental problems in the US

options.label: D
options.text: The movement only focused on the dangers of DDT and did not address other environmental issues

title: How can we solve the antibiotic resistance crisis? - Gerry Wright

options.label: C

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: That bacterial resistance had the potential to ruin the miracle of antibiotics

options.label: D

options.label: B
options.text: Because they were too expensive to produce

options.label: C

options.label: D
options.text: Because they were too difficult to discover

options.label: B
options.text: Through proteins that degrade the drug

options.label: C
options.text: Through sharing genetic information with other bacteria

options.label: D
options.text: All of the above

multiple-choice.question: What is one possible solution to incentivize antibiotic development?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: To shift profits away from the volume of antibiotics sold

options.label: C
options.text: To reduce the use of antibiotics in agriculture

options.label: D
options.text: To develop new vaccines for common infections

title: The tale of the doctor who defied Death - Iseult Gillespie

options.label: C
options.text: A large sum of money to help him start his career.

options.label: C

options.label: C

options.label: C
options.text: He made the doctor lose his fame and fortune.

options.label: D

title: What’s a squillo, and why do opera singers need it? Ming Luke
